Poverty and Death in Indonesian Gold
When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai reign in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour , the blasted Knolle is removed and swallowed with eager , unwashed hands .
Degei is sitting on the clay floor - she has no furniture - where she also carries out her daily work , such as washing clothes with muddy water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofed room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of the four wives of her husband , no fields were assigned to her .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , late working can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
No one dares to walk around in the village after 5 p.m. ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , which was taken up in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders were to vote in front of the occupying forces by means of a public intervention .

An existing movement campaigning for independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which maintains control of the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
Enarotari is as remote as it is öde .
There is no public transport .
The town of 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated iron roofs , which have been transformed by rust into different yellowish tones .
Few Indonesians have travelled here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago called Papuans a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not used to wearing these clothes ,  says Degei , pointing to her vivid , hand-woven turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .
'We used to have only leaves on our bodies ' .
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and have some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia 's gold land .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by Freeport McMoran from Phoenix , is just 60 miles from Paniai , a high-land province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , freeport has reduced gold and copper to $ 3.1 billion .
In addition , Papua has estimated $ 78 billion in wood resources .
But these riches are a source of misery for the Papua , ensuring that Indonesia ’ s powerful military maintains a suffocating presence .
A 2005 survey in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid local military personnel and units nearly $ 20 million between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten this golden goose and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal highlands in the 1970 ’ s became genocide , according to the Human Rights Commission of Asia .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

We Will Lose All  is a 2016 report by the Archdiocese of Brisbane , which contains reports of last year 's atrocities , such as illegal executions and torture - rape and electrical strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal repression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims because incidents occur every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesian researchers for Human Rights Watch .
The screws have increased as Papua 's resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

The population of 3.5 million inhabitants of the province is 83 % Christian , but demographic trends are changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java , Borneo , Sumatra and Sulawesi .
Javanese Warung Cantines sell roasted chicken and Gado-Gado , a mixed vegetable with peanut sauce .
Local people are fighting to stay here .

Migrants have started selling chickens and vegetables on the traditional market cheaper than the local Papua ,  explains Abeth You , a 24-year-old Paniai native who moved to the provincial capital Jayapura .
'It has cost the native Papua - the Mama-Mama [ women ] of Papua - their market ' .
Indonesian President Joko Widodo , popularly known as Jokowi , promised to address the inequalities and violations of the law in Papua during his 2014 campaign .
The former carpenter secured 27 of the 29 districts of Papua - including Paniai - on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But little has changed in Papua , and today the locals feel cheated .
Our hearts have been broken because we voted for Jokowi in 2014 , with the expectation that he will fulfill our hopes that justice will be restored ,  You said .
Indeed , only two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration in October , Paniai suffered a low .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children were out and sang Christmas songs in front of a campfire in Enarotari , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through the darkness on a motorcycle .
The frightened children told them that they should turn their headlights on .
One of the soldiers took offence at their tone and later returned with four soldiers , according to the local Pastor Yavedt Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk hunted and beat the group with their guns , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children .
A child , the 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was beaten so hard that he fell into the coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was set on fire and things escalated the next day .
About 1,000 young Papua men , women , and children gathered at a football pitch in front of the local police station and the military command center to demand justice .
They wore ceremonial hunting bows and performed the Waita dance - constantly imitating a bird song - by Papuas Mee Pago tribe .
